title: Michael Seifert (SS guard)
text:
Michael Seifert (16 March 1924 – 6 November 2010) was an <a href="Schutzstaffel">SS</a> guard in <a href="Italy">Italy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
He was an ethnic German born in <a href="Shyrokolanivka">Landau</a> (present-day <a href="Mykolaiv%20Oblast">Mykolaiv Oblast</a>, <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>). Dubbed the "Beast of Bolzano", he was convicted "<a href="trial%20in%20absentia">in absentia</a>" in 2000 by a <a href="military%20tribunal">military tribunal</a> in <a href="Verona">Verona</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, on nine counts of <a href="murder">murder</a>, committed while he was an SS guard at the <a href="Bolzano%20Transit%20Camp">Bolzano Transit Camp</a>, northern Italy.
He was sentenced to life in prison and <a href="Extradition">extradited</a> on 17 February 2008, from <a href="Canada">Canada</a> to Italy. His crimes involved actions taken in a prison camp in Bolzano from 1944 to 1945. At his trial, witnesses accused him of leaving a prisoner to starve to death, raping and killing a pregnant woman, and gouging an inmate's eyes out.
Avi Benlolo, president of the Friends of <a href="Simon%20Wiesenthal%20Center">Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust Studies</a> in Canada, noted that Seifert's imprisonment "sets an example for other <a href="war%20criminal">war criminal</a>s, not only Nazi war criminals, but war criminals related to <a href="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, <a href="Bosnia">Bosnia</a>, <a href="Darfur">Darfur</a>, or any other <a href="genocide">genocide</a>, that there's no time limit to <a href="justice">justice</a>".
After his extradition to Italy from Canada, Seifert was held in an Italian <a href="military%20prison">military prison</a> in <a href="Santa%20Maria%20Capua%20Vetere">Santa Maria Capua Vetere</a>. Prosecutors from Italy and <a href="Germany">Germany</a> intended to interview him regarding other war crimes that may have taken place at Bolzano.
He died in 2010 in Santa Maria after having been transferred to a hospital from the Capua Vetere prison. He was buried in a cemetery near Caserta after his body went unclaimed by friends and relatives. <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20120319223535/http%3A//www.suedtirolnews.it/d/artikel/2011/03/27/bestie-von-bozen-in-caserta-begraben.html"></a>
